turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I'm sorry, did you just call me "Lotte"?

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Do you mind?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: No, I guess not. I'm an actor.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh, my sweet, beautiful Lotte.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yes, Maxine, yes.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yes, yes, sweetheart, yes!  What the fuck is going on? I'm not talking. This is not me!

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh, Lotte...

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Something was making me talk. Some Goddamn thing was making me move. I gotta get out of here.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh, Dollface, it was just your passion for me taking hold.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: No, Dollface, I know what my passion taking hold feels like. I gotta go.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Darling!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: What the fuck is going on?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Come on in.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: I can explain about the portal, darling.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Don't con me, Maxine. We're over. I just let you up here to tell you that, and to tell you that I'm taking you and Schwartz to court.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh shut up.  Craig, darling are you in there?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yes. How did you know it was me?

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Lotte called me.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Oh, so the bitch escaped.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Apparently you can control this Malkovich fellow now.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I'm getting better all the time.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: I'll say you are. Let's do it on his kitchen table, then make him eat an omelette off of it.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: No... damn... you...  Oh shut up, you overrated sack of shit.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: You still there, sweets?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Yeah. I've figured out how to hold on as long as I want. Oddly enough, it's all in the wrists.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Wow.  Do a puppet show for me, Craig honey.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: You mean with Malkovich?

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: I'd love to see your work.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Really? Yeah. Okay.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: That was incredible. You're brilliant!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: You see, Maxine, it isn't just playing with dolls.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: You're right, my darling, it's so much more. It's playing with people!

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Stay in him forever?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: No!  But how will we make a living, my love, if our clientele doesn't have access to our product?

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Well, we'll have all the money in Malkovich's bank account, plus he still gets acting work occasionally.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: No! Please!  Shut up, will you? We're trying to think here.  It is sort of like being a puppeteer. I like that about it.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: No one would ever have to know its not him.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Wait a minute! What if everybody knew? What if we presented Malkovich as the world's most complicated puppet and me as the only puppeteer sophisticated enough to work him? We'd wipe the floor with the Great Mantini!

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh, Craiggy, that's brilliant!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Shut up!  Sorry, dear, I lost control for a minute.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: It's okay, my sweet.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Vegas.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Vegas. Can you arrange that?

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: This is it, lover. You're stepping onto that stage a nobody and presto-change-o, you're coming back the greatest puppeteer the world has ever seen.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I'm nervous. Malkovich is fighting me hard today.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Doesn't he know how important tonight is to us?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: He's a selfish bastard.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: They love me, darling! "Craig Schwartz is fantastic!"  The New York Times. "If only Craig Schwartz had always been inside Malkovich!"  Women's Wear Daily. "Craig Schwartz - The world's greatest puppeteer!"  Paul Wunder, WBAI Radio.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Oh, darling. It's a dream come true. We're going to ride this straight to the top.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Sleepy suddenly.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Busy day, my little fire chief. Why don't you climb into bed, and I'll meet you there in just...

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Bad dream, darling?

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I've got to leave Malkovich.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: You've got to be kidding.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: I just had the most horrifying nightmare. The devil was in it.

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Honey, we can be happy and poor together.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Perhaps you'll want to consult that Ouija board again.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Yeah what?!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Derek Mantini!

turns.speaker: MALKOVICH
turns.text: Good-bye, Maxine.

turns.speaker: MAXINE
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: TINY WOMAN
turns.text: Captain Mertin?

turns.speaker: MERTIN
turns.text: What want ye, girl child?

turns.speaker: TINY WOMAN
turns.text: I am not a child, Captain Mertin, but rather an adult lady of miniature proportions.

turns.speaker: MERTIN
turns.text: I see. Well, it is not my fault that thou art tiny. So if it is charity yer after, then be gone with ye, ye foul demon.

turns.speaker: TINY WOMAN
turns.text: I am not asking for alms, but rather the ear of a kind man with a noble heart.

turns.speaker: MERTIN
turns.text: Aye. Speak then if ye must.

turns.speaker: TINY WOMAN
turns.text: Captain Mertin, surely I am a God-fearing Christian woman like yourself, but alas, I am afraid that the world was not built with me in mind. Door knobs are too high, chairs are unwieldy, high-ceilinged rooms mock my stature. Nor am I a marrie lady, Captain. after all, who would marry a person of my diminutiveness? So I am forced to work for my few pennies a week as an optometrist. Why cannot there be a place for me to work safe and comfortable?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Why you never go back to Lady Jone's and learn your letters? You liked going there I remember. Seeing the other children. Then all a sudden, you stop.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: There was a boy there...said mama was a jailbird...said he could prove it..

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: You got to go sometime. You got to go out there by yourself sometime.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: But you said...you said out there, there ain't no...what was that word?..no..de- fense. No de-fense.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: There ain't.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Then what do I do?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Know it, and go on out the yard. Go on.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Folks came.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Folks come. Folks go.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Here, let me carry that.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: I got a delivery around here. Name of Tucker.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Yonder. Twin chestnuts in the yard.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Well what?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: This Saturday - you coming to Call or what?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: If I call them, and they come what on earth am I going to say to them.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Say the Word!

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: The Word. What you was put here to speak.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: That's the last thing they took from me.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: But you got to do it. You got to. Can't nobody Call like you. You have to be there.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: What I have to do is get in my bed and lay down. I want to fix on something harmless in this world.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: What world are you talking about? Ain't nothing harmless down here.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Blue. That doesn't hurt nobody. Yellow neither.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You getting into bed to think about yellow?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: I likes yellow.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Then what? When you get through with blue and yellow, then what?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Can't say. It's something can't be planned.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You blaming God. That what you're doing?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: No, Stamp. I ain't.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You saying whitefolks won. That what you saying?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Those white things have taken all I had or dreamed. I'm saying ain't no bad luck in this world 'cept for white folks..They just don't know when to stop.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You saying nothing counts?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: I'm saying they came into my yard.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You saying God give up? Nothing left for us but pour out our own blood?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: I'm saying they came into my yard.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You punishing Him, ain't you?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Not like He punished me.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You can't do that, Baby. It ain't right.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Was a time I knew what was.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You still know.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: What I know is what I see: a nigger woman hauling shoes.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Aw, Baby.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: We have to be steady. "These things too will pass". What you looking for? A miracle?

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: No. I'm looking for what I was put here to look for: the back door.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: No. Sorry.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Ah, winter in Ohio is especially rough if you've got an appetite for color.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: They'll be all right. I'm surprised they lasted here this long.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe we should have moved.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: What'd be the point? Not a house in the country ain't packed to the rafters with some dead Negro's grief. We lucky our ghost is a baby. My husband spirit come back? Or yours? Don't talk to me! Ha..You lucky. You got one child left, still pullin at your skirts. Be thankful. I had eight. Eight with six fathers. Every one of them gone from me. Four taken, four chased and all, I expect, worrying somebody's house into evil. My first born - alls I can remember of her now is how she loved the burned bottom of bread. Her little hands..I wouldn't know'em if they slapped me. Can you beat that? Eight children and that's all I remember.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: You remember Halle.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Oh, I remember bits and pieces of all of'em I guess..Halle, of course..I had Halle a lifetime. Almost twenty years... My two girls, sold and gone before I could even a heard about it, and them without their grown up teeth yet. My third child, my son after Halle...I let that straw boss have me for four months so's I could keep that boy. Next year, he had him traded for lumber anyway and me pregnant with his child. I couldn't love that child. I wouldn't. Not any of the rest either. God take what He would....and He did...

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: The boys wouldn't have left if Halle were here.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: Those boys didn't even know him. You had six whole years of marriage to my Halle Fathered every one of your children. A blessing. I learned hard that a man's just a man, but a son like that...like Halle..now that's somebody.

turns.speaker: BABY SUGGS
turns.text: ...All I remember is how she loved the bottom of burned bread. Her little hands...I wouldn't know 'em if they slapped me".

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: ..."Here. Look here. See this mark? If you can't tell me by my face, look here."

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: ..I swallowed her blood right along with my mother's milk. She played with me and always came to be with me whenever I needed her. Me and her waited for our daddy. I love her. I do. She never hurt me. I love my mother but I know she killed one of her own, and tender as she is with me, I'm scared of her because of it. All the time, I'm afraid the thing that happened that made it all right to kill her own, could happen again. Whatever it is, it comes from outside this house, outside the yard. So I never leave this house and I watch over the yard so it can't happen again ... I have to keep it away from my sister...I'll protect Beloved...'Cause She's mine...

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Beloved..She's mine       I am Beloved

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: and she is mine...

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: YOU HURT ME.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I WILL PROTECT YOU.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: WATCH OUT FOR HER; SHE CAN GIVE YOU DREAMS.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: WHERE ARE THE MEN WITHOUT SKIN?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: THE WHITEFOLK?

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: What do you know about it? I sleep where I want.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: You best leave that quilt alone. That was grandma's quilt.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: DID YOU COME FROM THE OTHER SIDE.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: YES. I WAS ON THE OTHER SIDE.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: YOU CAME BACK BECAUSE OF ME?

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: YES.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: YOU NEVER FORGOT ME?

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: YOUR FACE IS MINE.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: WILL YOU STAY?

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: WHY DID YOU LEAVE ME WHO AM YOU?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: I WILL NEVER LEAVE YOU AGAIN.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: CAN THEY GET IN HERE?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: NO. THEY TRIED ONCE BUT I STOPPED THEM. THEY WON'T EVER COME BACK...YOU MY BEST THING.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: You don't sit with me!!

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Baby, don't be like that.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: You don't sit with me!! I don't sit with people who leave me!

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Don't talk like that. Your mama loves you.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: I had another dream last night.  The dead man laying on top of me and I had nothing to eat. And the ghosts without skin stuck their fingers in me and said Beloved in the dark and bitch in the light..

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Don't say those things. You forget about those dreams..

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: You gave me the bad dreams. You left me behind...

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Mama told you - I'd give up my own life, every minute, every hour of it to take back one of your tears baby...My children my best thing. You my best thing!

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: You're weren't nice to me..you didn't smile at me..

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: That's not true. I told you, I had to get you out, make you safe...so's you and me could be together on the other side, forever..

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: I want somethin' sweet.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: We don't have nothing sweet no more, baby.

turns.speaker: BELOVED
turns.text: Not for me, you don't! You don't let me eat the pies...

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: No. Since mama lost her job, we don't have no more pies..

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, is it now? How you getting along?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Don't pay to complain.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You on your way home?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: No. Got me an afternoon job at the shirt factory. Figure between that and my night work at the Bodwins I might be able to put something away for me and mama.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They treating you right over at the Bodwins?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: More than all right. Miss Bodwin, she teach me stuff..Book stuff. She says I might go to Oberlin. She's experimenting on me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Your mother all right?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: No. Not a bit all right. Hasn't gotten out of bed since that day.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You think I should stop by? Think she'd welcome it?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I don't know. I think I've lost my mother, Paul D.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: That girl...You know, Beloved...

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She gone like they say?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Haven't seen her since that day. Ella thinks she might be waiting in the woods for another chance but..I don't think so. Mama thinks she's gone for good. Says she can feel it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You think she sure 'nough your sister?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: At times. At other times I think she was...more. But who would know that better than you. I mean, you sure 'nough you her.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, if you want my opinion...

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I don't. I have my own.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You grown.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Yes sir

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, good luck with the job.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: And Paul D...you don't have to stay 'way, but be careful how you talk to my mama, hear?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: May I come in?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: What you want?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I want to see Mr. and Mrs. Bodwin.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Miss Bodwin. They brother and sister, darlin.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: What you want'em for?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I'm looking for work. I was thinking they might know of some.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: You Baby Sugg's kin, ain't you?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: I heard your mother took sick, that so?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Yes ma'am..

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Well, come on in. You letting in flies.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: You know what? I've been here since I was fourteen and I remember like yesterday when Baby Suggs, holy, came here and sat right where you are. Whiteman name of Garner brought her. He and Mr. Bodwin were good friends. That's how she got that house you all live in. Other things too.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: I never went to those woodland services but she was always nice to me. Always. Never be another like her.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I miss her.

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Bet you do. Everybody miss her. That was a good woman...Well, I don't know whether the Bodwins think it or not but they sure could use some extra help.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Ya think?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: They getting older now and I can't take care of 'em like I used to. More and more they keep asking me to sleep over night. Now, I don't want to quit these people but they can't have all my days and nights too. I got my own family needs me. It'll take some convincing but maybe you could come after supper - take care of your mama during the day, then earn a little something at night, how's that?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Fine. But what would I do at night?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Be here. In case.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: In case of what?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: In case the house burn down or bad weather slops the roads so bad I can't get here on time or late guests needed cleaning up after. Anything.  Don't ask me what whitefolks need at night.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: They good whitefolks?

turns.speaker: JANEY
turns.text: Oh yeah. They good. Can't say they ain't good. I wouldn't trade them for another pair, tell you that. But you come back in a few days - give me a chance to lead'em to it. All right?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I want to work, Miss Lady.

turns.speaker: LADY JONES
turns.text: Work? Start learnin your letters again?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: No. I mean work work.

turns.speaker: LADY JONES
turns.text: Well, what can you do?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: I can't do anything but I would learn it for you if you have a little extra.

turns.speaker: LADY JONES
turns.text: Extra?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Food. My mama, she doesn't feel well. I couldn't stay away from her too long, cause of her condition but I could do chores in the mornings.

turns.speaker: LADY JONES
turns.text: Oh baby...I don't know anyone could pay anybody anything for work they did themselves...But if you all need to eat until your mother's well, all you have to do is say so...We have a church committee invented so nobody had to go hungry.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: No..No that won't do...

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Back stiff?

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: OOh, yeah...Don't know if it's the floor or the skating.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Could be that fall you took.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: That was fun.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Should I wake her?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: No, let her rest.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: She likes to see you off in the morning.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: I'll make sure she does. But first I'm going  make up a nice, big breakfast against that cold outside.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Won't you be late for work?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Don't matter. First time I'll be late in nine years. No great trouble..Whatever goes on out there goes on with or without me showing up on time... don't matter...  The world is in this room, baby. This is all there is and all there needs to be.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: DON'T LOVE HER TOO MUCH.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: DO YOU FORGIVE ME?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: OUT THERE. WAY OFF.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: DADDY IS COMING FOR US.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Morning, ma'am.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: MAMA!

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Hold back Denver - I'm fine..You..you go on upstairs. I'll do the cleaning up.

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: But mama..

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Go upstairs I said!!

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Mama let me help you.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: NO!...She wanted me to do it.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Nobody..no sir..that's right..nobody's going be doing that..nobody going be writing my daughter's characteristics on the animal side..no sir..I don't care..ain't laying that down..no sir. I refuse..that's right..that's right...

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Mama...Mama she's asleep. Why don't you eat something.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: She likes this dress...

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: But you'll hurt your eyes doin it there. Come sit at the table.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: No...no...no..

turns.speaker: DENVER
turns.text: Mama?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Where you been keeping yourself? I told John must be cold if Stamp stay inside.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Oh I been out.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Out where?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Was over to Baby Suggs.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: What you want there? Somebody invite you in?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: That's Baby's kin. I don't need no invite to look after her people.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Somebody new there. A woman. Thought you might know who she is.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Ain't no new Negroes in this town I don't know about. What she look like? You sure that wasn't Denver?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I know Denver.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I know what I see.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Might see anything at all at 124.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: True.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Better ask Paul D.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Can't locate him.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: He's sleeping in the church.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: The church!

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Yeah. Asked Rev. Pike if he could stay in the cellar.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: It's cold as charity in there! What he do that for? Any number'll take him in.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Can't nobody read minds long distance. All he have to do is ask somebody.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Why? Why he have to ask? Can't nobody offer? What's going on? Since when a black man come to town have to sleep in the cellar like a dog?!

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Unrile yourself, Stamp. It's only a few days he been there.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: NO! Shouldn't be no days! You know all about it and don't give him a hand? That don't sound like you, Ella. Me and you been pulling colored folk out the water more'n twenty years! Now you tell me you can't offer a man a bed?! A working man who can pay his own way?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: He ask, I give him anything.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Why's that necessary all of a sudden?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: I don't know him that well.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You know he's colored? What else there to know?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Stamp, don't tear me up this morning! I don't feel like it.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: It's her, ain't it?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Her who?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Sethe. He took up with her and stayed in there and you don't want nothing to-

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Hold on! Don't jump if you can't see bottom!

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Girl, give it up! We been friends too long to act like this.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Well, who can tell what went on in there? I never even knew who Sethe was or none of her people.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You know she married Baby Suggs' boy.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: I ain't sure I know that. Baby never laid eyes on her till she showed up here. And how'd she make it and her husband didn't? And where is he? And how she have that baby in the woods by herself? Said a whitewoman help her. Shoot. You believe that? Well, I know what kind of white that was.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Aw, no, Ella.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Anything white floating around in the woods - if it don't got a shotgun, it's something the Lord tells me I don't want no part of.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You was friends.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Till she showed herself.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Ella.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: I ain't got no friends take a handsaw to their own children.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: What's any of that got to do with Paul D.?

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: What run him off? Tell me that!

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I run him off.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I told him...Showed him the newspaper. About Sethe. Read it to him. He left that very day.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: You didn't tell me that. I thought he already knew.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: He didn't know nothing. And nobody. Except her, from when they was at that place Baby Suggs was at.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: He knew Baby Suggs?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Sure he knew her. Her boy Halle, too.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: And he left when he found out what Sethe did?  What you say casts a different light on it, I guess...I thought-

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: But you didn't come here talking 'bout Paul. You came asking about a new girl.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: That's so.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: Well, Paul D. must know who she is. Or what she is.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You mind loaded with spirits. Everywhere you look you see one.

turns.speaker: ELLA
turns.text: You know as well as I do, Stamp, that people who die bad don't stay in the ground.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: This is hard for me. But I got to do it. Two things I got to say to you. I'm a take the easy one first.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If it's hard for you, might kill me dead.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I come looking for you to ask your pardon. Apologize.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You pick any house, any house where colored live. Pick any one and you welcome to stay there. I'm apologizing 'cause they didn't offer to tell you. But you welcome anywhere you want to be. My house. John and Ella. Miss Lady Jones..anybody. You choose. You ain't got to sleep in no cellar and I apologize for each and every night.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well I...I did get offered one place but I just wanted to be off by myself a spell.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Oh yeah. Oh that's load off. I thought everybody gone crazy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Just me.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You planning to do anything about it?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh yeah. I got big plans.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You remember your price, Stamp?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Never found out.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I did. Down to the cent.$900. Always wondered though what Mrs. Garner got for my brother Paul F. Must of been more than nine hundred dollars cause she use that money for Sweet Home for almost two years. But then they hung my other brother Paul A. up on a tree so I guess he wasn't worth the same..I wonder what was Baby Suggs worth? And Halle? I wasn't surprised when I found out they tracked down Sethe all the way to Cincinatti. Her price must have been higher than all of us - her being property that reproduced itself without cost. A breeder.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: No use thinking these things now.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh but we got to. How we gonna know our price in the future? How are children's children's children gonna know what they cost? Who's gonna tell them? What are they gonna pay for us, if we free?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Children ain't gonna need to know that kind of thing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They'll know. They'll know as soon as they born. Cause it's inside us,Stamp. It'll be inside them. We'll pass it down. Schoolteacher didn't just change the outside, he changed the mind..and the blood..and what it carries...and what it's worth..

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I don't believe that. I won't.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: There was a rooster named Mister down at Sweet Home. Last time I saw Halle, with that butter all over his face and me with an iron bit in my mouth, I saw Mister - sitting on a tub. He loved that tub. Like king on a throne. He was a hateful thing. Bloody and evil..But he was better than me.  Mister was allowed to be and stay what he was. Even if you cooked him you'd be cooking a rooster named Mister. But wasn't no way I'd ever be Paul D. again..Schoolteacher changed me. Was never no beating under Mr. Garner. Schoolteacher changed that. Why wouldn't a man run from that? Why wouldn't a man not work, kill, starve, pull out his own heart to stop feeling 'stead of feeling that? And it strikes me, it's got to be cause we were something else. And that something was less than a chicken sitting in the sun on a tub.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I said I had two things to say to you. I only told you one. I have to tell you the other.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't want to know.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: I was there Paul D...There in the yard. When she did it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What yard? When who-

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: It ain't what you think.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You don't know what I think.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: She ain't crazy. She love those children. She was trying to outhurt the hurter's all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Leave off..

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: She was only-

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Stamp, leave off I said! I knew her when she was a girl. She scares me and I knew her when she was a girl...

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: You ain't scared of Sethe. I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She scares me. I scare me. And that girl in her house scares me.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Who is she? Where she come from?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't know. Just shot up one day from a stump.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: She what run you off? Not what I told you 'bout Sethe?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Tell me something, Stamp. Tell me this one thing. How much is a nigger supposed to take?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: All he can. All he can.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why? Why? Why? Why? Why?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Sethe?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Paul D.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: You shaved.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah. Look bad?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: No, You looking good.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Devil's confusion. What's this I hear about you not getting out of bed?  I saw Denver. She tell you?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: She comes in the daytime.  She still with me, my Denver.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You got to get up from here, girl.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: I'm tired, Paul. So tired. I have to rest a while.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't you die on me!! This is Baby Suggs quilt. Is that what you planning!?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Oh, I don't have no plans. No plans at all.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Look - Denver be here in the day. I be here in the night. I'm a take care of you, you hear? Starting now.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What, baby?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: She left me. She's gone again.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Aw, girl. Don't cry...Me and you, we got more yesterday than anybody. We need some kind of tomorrow...

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: She was my best thing.

turns.speaker: SAWYER
turns.text: What the hell you thinking, girl? Strolling in here this late?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Don't talk to me, Mr. Sawyer. Don't say nothing to me this morning.

turns.speaker: SAWYER
turns.text: What? What? You talking back to me?

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: I'm telling you don't say nothing to me.

turns.speaker: SAWYER
turns.text: Not too sweet! You make it too sweet they don't eat it.

turns.speaker: SETHE
turns.text: Make it the way I always do.

turns.speaker: SAWYER
turns.text: Yeah. Too sweet.

turns.speaker: WHITE MAN
turns.text: Hey!!

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: WHITE MAN
turns.text: I'm looking for a gal name of Judy. Works over by the slaughterhouse. Said she lived on Plank Road.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Plank Road. Yes sir. That's up a ways. Mile, maybe.

turns.speaker: WHITE MAN
turns.text: You don't know her? Judy? Works in the slaughterhouse.

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: No sir, I don't, but I know Plank Road. 'Bout a mile up thataway.

turns.speaker: WHITE MAN
turns.text: Look here..There's a cross up there, so I guess this here's a church or used to be. Seems to me like you ought to show it some respect, you follow me?

turns.speaker: STAMP PAID
turns.text: Yes sir..You right about that. That's just what I come over to talk to him about. Just that..

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Hiya Allan.

turns.speaker: ALLAN
turns.text: Dude, I finally got the venue I wanted.  I'm Performing my dance quintet--you know, my cycle--at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night, and I'd love it if you came and gave me notes.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Sure Allan, I'll be there.

turns.speaker: ALLAN
turns.text: Dude, uh, tomorrow is already the tenth.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah I know. Okay.

turns.speaker: ALLAN
turns.text: Just, uh, just slip the rent under my door.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Yeah, okay.

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BLOND MAN
turns.text: Wasn't this guy supposed to be a millionaire?

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: Uh?

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: Fuck.

turns.speaker: BLOND MAN
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: He looks like a fuckin' loser.

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: Pin your diapers on, Lebowski.  Jackie Treehorn wants to see you.

turns.speaker: BLOND MAN
turns.text: And we know which Lebowski you are, Lebowski.

turns.speaker: WOO
turns.text: Yeah.  Jackie Treehorn wants to talk to the deadbeat Lebowski.

turns.speaker: BLOND MAN
turns.text: You're not dealing with morons here.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Manolo will load it into your car for you, uh, Dude.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: It's the LeBaron.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Well, enjoy, and perhaps we'll see you again some time, Dude.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Yeah sure, if I'm ever in the neighborhood, need to use the john.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: We've had some terrible news.  Mr. Lebowski is in seclusion in the West Wing.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Mr. Lebowski is prepared to make a generous offer to you to act as courier once we get instructions for the money.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Why me, man?

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: He suspects that the culprits might be the very people who, uh, soiled your rug, and you're in a unique position to confirm or, uh, disconfirm that suspicion.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: So he thinks it's the carpet-pissers, huh?

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Well Dude, we just don't know.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: They called about eighty minutes ago.  They want you to take the money and drive north on the 4 5.  They'll call you on the portable phone with instructions in about forty minutes. One person only or I'd go with you. They were very clear on that: one person only.  What happened to your jaw?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Oh, nothin', you know.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Here's the money, and the phone. Please, Dude, follow whatever instructions they give.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Her life is in your hands.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Oh, man, don't say that..

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Mr. Lebowski asked me to repeat that: Her life is in your hands.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Her life is in your hands, Dude. And report back to us as soon as it's done.

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: This is our concern, Dude.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: No, man, nothing is fucked here--

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: That had not occurred to us, Dude.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Well, okay, you're not privy to all the new shit, so uh, you know, but that's what you pay me for.  Speaking of which, would it be possible for me to get my twenty grand in cash? I gotta check this with my accountant of course, but my concern is that, you know, it could bump me into a higher tax--

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Where'd she been?

turns.speaker: BRANDT
turns.text: Visiting friends of hers in Palm Springs.  Just picked up and left, never bothered to tell us.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: But I guess she told Dieter.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: I know my rights.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: You don't know shit, Lebowski.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: I want a fucking lawyer, man.  I want Bill Kunstler.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: What are you, some kind of sad-assed refugee from the fucking sixties?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Mr. Treehorn tells us that he had to eject you from his garden party, that you were drunk and abusive.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: That guy treats women like objects, man.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Mr. Treehorn draws a lot of water in this town, Lebowski.  You don't draw shit.  We got a nice quiet beach community here, and I aim to keep it nice and quiet.  So let me make something plain.  I don't like you sucking around bothering our citizens, Lebowski.  I don't like your jerk- off name, I don't like your jerk-off face, I don't like your jerk- off behavior, and I don't like you, jerk- off --do I make myself clear?

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: A dick, man!  And let me tell you something: I dig your work. Playing one side against the other--in bed with everybody--fabulous stuff, man.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: I'm not a--ah, fuck it, just stay away from my fucking lady friend, man.

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: Hey hey, I'm not messing with your special lady--

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: She's not my special lady, she's my fucking lady friend.  I'm just helping her conceive, man!

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: Hey, man, I'm not--

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Who're you working for?  Lebowski? Jackie Treehorn?

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: The Gundersons.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: The?  Who the fff--

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: The Gundersons.  It's a wandering daughter job.  Bunny Lebowski, man. Her real name is Fawn Gunderson. Her parents want her back.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Jesus fucking Christ.

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: Crazy, huh?  Ran away a year ago.

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: Fuck, man!  That's terrible!

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Yeah, it sucks.

turns.speaker: DA FINO
turns.text: Well maybe you and me could pool our resources--trade information-- professional courtesy--compeers, you know--

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: There's no ransom if you don't have a fucking hostage.  That's what ransom is.  Those are the fucking rules.

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: Zere ARE no ROOLZ!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: NO RULES!  YOU CABBAGE-EATING SONS- OF- BITCHES--

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: Okay.  Vee take ze money you haf on you und vee call it eefen.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: VEE FUCK YOU UP, MAN!  VEE TAKE YOUR MONEY!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Come and get it.

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: VEE FUCK YOU UP, MAN!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Come and get it.  Fucking nihilist.

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: I FUCK YOU!  I FUCK YOU!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Show me what you got.  Nihilist. Dipshit with a nine-toed woman.

turns.speaker: DIETER
turns.text: NUSSING!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: ANTI-SEMITE!

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: Yes.  I understand you're taking away the remains.

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Can we just rent it from you?

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: Sir, this is a mortuary, not a rental house.

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: Sir, please lower your voice--

turns.speaker: DUDE
turns.text: Hey man, don't you have something else you could put it in?

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: That is our most modestly priced receptacle.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DONNELLY
turns.text: We have the urn.
